What's the latest with Trump and Venezuela?

The latest is a U.S. seizure of a Venezuelan‑linked oil supertanker off Venezuela’s coast, followed by expanded sanctions and sharp diplomatic blowback, pushing maritime risk higher around Venezuela [M2, 1, 2, 3, 5].

## TL;DR
- U.S. seized the VLCC “Skipper” on Dec 10–11; Caracas called it “piracy” [M2, 1, 2].  
- Washington widened sanctions on Maduro‑linked individuals and ships; markets and tanker traffic reacted to the heightened risk [M2, 3].  
- Trump has also warned of possible land‑based strikes “soon,” further elevating tensions [5].

## Key developments
- Tanker seizure: U.S. forces boarded and seized the VLCC Skipper in international waters; video was posted by the U.S. attorney general; Trump touted the operation publicly [M2, 2].  
- Diplomatic fallout: Venezuela, joined by Cuba and Iran, denounced the action as “international piracy” [M2, 1].  
- Sanctions surge: Treasury targeted Maduro‑linked individuals (including the so‑called “narco nephews”) and multiple ships tied to Venezuelan oil trades [M2, 3].  
- Threats of further action: Trump warned of potential land strikes against targets in Venezuela “soon” (no timeline given) [5].  
- Market/traffic impact: Oil prices ticked up on the news; maritime advisories note slower tanker movements and higher perceived risk near Venezuelan waters [M2].

## Why it matters
- Energy flows: Disruptions to Venezuelan crude shipments can ripple into regional supply chains and global pricing [M2].  
- Regional security: Increased U.S.–Venezuela friction raises risks of further maritime confrontations and legal disputes over sanctions enforcement [M2].  
- Domestic stakes: Caracas uses the episode to rally support; Washington signals continued enforcement against sanctioned oil trades [M2].

## What to watch
- Additional interdictions or seizures targeting sanctioned cargoes [M2].  
- Any backchannel talks or regional mediation to cool tensions [M2].  
- Changes in tanker routing/AIS behavior, insurance costs, and port calls around Venezuela [M2].  
- Whether threats of land‑based strikes translate into new military actions [5].

webResultsPreview.title: Why is Trump attacking Venezuelan boats? | The Latest | Donald Trump | The Guardian
webResultsPreview.snippet: US forces have seized an oil tanker off the coast of Venezuela in a major escalation of Donald Trump’s campaign against the country’s president, Nicolás Maduro, whose government called the seizure an act of international piracy.

webResultsPreview.title: Analysis: What Trump’s latest dramatic Venezuela move means | CNN Politics
webResultsPreview.snippet: This image from video posted on Attorney General Pam Bondi's X account, and partially redacted by the source, shows an oil tanker being seized by US forces off the coast of Venezuela, on December 10, 2025.

webResultsPreview.title: Scoop: Trump sanctions Maduro's nephews, 6 ships carrying Venezuela oil
webResultsPreview.snippet: Why it matters: The new sanctions, to be announced by Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, are the latest aspect of President Trump's pressure campaign on Maduro, whom the administration has accused of leading a narco-trafficking terrorist organization. "Nicolas Maduro and his criminal associates in Venezuela are flooding the United States with drugs that are poisoning the American people," Bessent said in written statement obtained by Axios.

webResultsPreview.title: Maduro trapped with few retaliation options after Trump admin seizes Venezuelan oil tanker
webResultsPreview.snippet: Trump administration seizes Venezuela oil tanker, leaving Maduro regime with few retaliation options that wouldn't harm its own cash-starved government.

webResultsPreview.title: Venezuela latest: Trump threatens land strikes 'soon' - and sanctions 'narco nephews' | World News | Sky News
webResultsPreview.snippet: Leavitt said the vessel will sail ... oil. She added that Donald Trump isn't interested in a conflict with Venezuela but wants to see the "end of illegal drugs being trafficked into the United States"....
